content.raw:
Here is my original email to the team on this issue and the associated tutorial - posted here for posterity.

---

With the current thruster configuration scenario \(as described in wiki and the Technical Guide\) we run the risk of getting perhaps unintended solutions. For example, a team could put all four thrusters in the stern, effectively giving themselves double the control authority. However, it is a positive to allow the teams the flexibility to configure their system to be as close as possible to their actual vehicle.

Here is one alternative we might consider. 

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/2936587970-wamv_thruster_zones.png)
If we define a set of multiple compliant "zones" for placing thrusters where **teams can use up to four thrusters and no more than one thruster in each zone**. See the attached image with five zones. This would allow teams the flexibility to determine their type of propulsion configuration \(H, T, X, etc.\) and to modify the specific location and orientation of the thrusters.

Below are some comments on the wiki. I don't think finalizing the configuration wiki is on the critical path for getting the release done today, but here are some thoughts that might help clarify and help the teams as they start working on through the examples.

* Pointing to `wamv_description/urdf/thrusters/ `for descriptions is a bit confusing. The engine.xacro defines the visual elements, but perhaps more importantly, the plugin parameters are over in [#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv\_gazebo/urdf/thruster\_layouts/wamv\_gazebo\_thruster\_config.xacro](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv_gazebo/urdf/thruster_layouts/wamv_gazebo_thruster_config.xacro)

    * Not sure if there is a clean way to describe this to folks - could consider centralizing the descriptions in one place for release 1.2?
    
* I'm not sure what we mean by "all possible thruster and sensor configurations are in compliance"?
* Should we limit the orientation of thruster placement to yaw only? I don't think we want to deal with pitch and roll for thrusters.
* Could the example YAML config files be included in the repo? Then your demo would have two parts - Part 1 would illustrate calling the generator script for the existing files \(this could only support working from source or provide a wget commend to download the yaml files\). Part 2 could describe how folks could do the same for their own files.

    * Would we have config file examples in the repo to generate our typical H, T and X configurations?
    
* I'm curious why configure\_wamv.py is written as a ROS node \(using ROS parameters as input and a launch file\) - instead of as a standalone script? I'm assuming this has something to do with the automated evaluation workflow.
* I would have the thruster example generate something that is more typical of RobotX. Using the example of three thrusters at the stern suggests that this would be a reasonable custom configuration.
content.html:
Here is my original email to the team on this issue and the associated tutorial - posted here for posterity.

With the current thruster configuration scenario (as described in wiki and the Technical Guide) we run the risk of getting perhaps unintended solutions. For example, a team could put all four thrusters in the stern, effectively giving themselves double the control authority. However, it is a positive to allow the teams the flexibility to configure their system to be as close as possible to their actual vehicle.

Here is one alternative we might consider.

If we define a set of multiple compliant "zones" for placing thrusters where teams can use up to four thrusters and no more than one thruster in each zone. See the attached image with five zones. This would allow teams the flexibility to determine their type of propulsion configuration (H, T, X, etc.) and to modify the specific location and orientation of the thrusters.

Below are some comments on the wiki. I don't think finalizing the configuration wiki is on the critical path for getting the release done today, but here are some thoughts that might help clarify and help the teams as they start working on through the examples.

  • Pointing to wamv_description/urdf/thrusters/for descriptions is a bit confusing. The engine.xacro defines the visual elements, but perhaps more importantly, the plugin parameters are over in #!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv_gazebo/urdf/thruster_layouts/wamv_gazebo_thruster_config.xacro

    • Not sure if there is a clean way to describe this to folks - could consider centralizing the descriptions in one place for release 1.2?

  • I'm not sure what we mean by "all possible thruster and sensor configurations are in compliance"?

  • Should we limit the orientation of thruster placement to yaw only? I don't think we want to deal with pitch and roll for thrusters.

  • Could the example YAML config files be included in the repo? Then your demo would have two parts - Part 1 would illustrate calling the generator script for the existing files (this could only support working from source or provide a wget commend to download the yaml files). Part 2 could describe how folks could do the same for their own files.

    • Would we have config file examples in the repo to generate our typical H, T and X configurations?

  • I'm curious why configure_wamv.py is written as a ROS node (using ROS parameters as input and a launch file) - instead of as a standalone script? I'm assuming this has something to do with the automated evaluation workflow.

  • I would have the thruster example generate something that is more typical of RobotX. Using the example of three thrusters at the stern suggests that this would be a reasonable custom configuration.

content.raw: I believe this PR addresses all of these issues nicely.  @{5b96b66385af94340e7cabce} is working on cleaning up the wiki and doing a code review.  I’ll plan to do a quick review and hopefully merge tomorrow.
content.html: I believe this PR addresses all of these issues nicely. @Tyler Lum is working on cleaning up the wiki and doing a code review. I’ll plan to do a quick review and hopefully merge tomorrow.

content.raw: Since you now define defaults for these parameters how would a user only customize the thrusters OR the sensors.  Do we expect that users will always supply yaml files for both?  It appears that in configure\_wamv.py you allowed for users to not necessarily specify both.
content.html: Since you now define defaults for these parameters how would a user only customize the thrusters OR the sensors. Do we expect that users will always supply yaml files for both? It appears that in configure_wamv.py you allowed for users to not necessarily specify both.

content.raw: Yes this is how this code currently works. I think that it is not a bad behavior. ie: if I only care about my thruster config right now, I only give a thruster yaml and I get default sensors config, which my real eventual sensors config wont be far from, and vice versa for sensors.
content.html: Yes this is how this code currently works. I think that it is not a bad behavior. ie: if I only care about my thruster config right now, I only give a thruster yaml and I get default sensors config, which my real eventual sensors config wont be far from, and vice versa for sensors.

content.raw:
Got it.  I think we should mention that in the documentation wiki.

Also, it might help if we we had `default_sensor_config.yaml` and `default_thruster_config.yaml` files that were used to make this a bit more obvious.
content.html:
Got it. I think we should mention that in the documentation wiki.

Also, it might help if we we had default_sensor_config.yaml and default_thruster_config.yaml files that were used to make this a bit more obvious.

      orientation: "0.0 0.0 0.0"
    - prefix: "right"
      position: "-2.373776 -1.027135 0.318237"
      orientation: "0.0 0.0 0.0"

      position: "-2.373776 1.027135 0.318237"

content.raw: Not strictly part of this PR, but I notice in `configure_wamv.py` we implicitly assume we receive ‘wamv\_target’ and ‘wamv\_gazebo’ parameters.  Might worth adding some validation that these are received and printing a helpful error if they are not.
content.html: Not strictly part of this PR, but I notice in configure_wamv.py we implicitly assume we receive ‘wamv_target’ and ‘wamv_gazebo’ parameters. Might worth adding some validation that these are received and printing a helpful error if they are not.

content.raw:
so right now

‘wamv\_gazebo’ will alwasy be set by  <param name="wamv\_gazebo" value="$\(find wamv\_gazebo\)/urdf/wamv\_gazebo.urdf.xacro"/>

and not setting 'wamv\_target' will give and error:

RLException: \[/home/marshall/vrx\_ws/src/vrx/vrx\_gazebo/launch/generate\_wamv.launch\] requires the 'wamv\_target' arg to be set

content.raw:
If I use a thruster yaml like this…

```
engine:
  - prefix: "left"
    position: "-2.373776 1.027135 0.318237"
    orientation: "0.0 0.0 0.0"
  - prefix: "left2"
    position: "-2.373776 1.027135 0.318237"
    orientation: "0.0 0.0 0.0"
```

I get an error that…

```
[ERROR] [1562799959.203618]: engine left2 is out of bounds
[ERROR] [1562799959.204430]: engine left2 is at xyz=(-2.373776, 1.027135, 0.318237), it must fit in at least one of the following boxes:
```

I would expect an error that says I have exceeded the number of allowable items in the particular box?

    orientation: "0.0 0.0 0.0"

I get an error that…

[ERROR] [1562799959.203618]: engine left2 is out of bounds
[ERROR] [1562799959.204430]: engine left2 is at xyz=(-2.373776, 1.027135, 0.318237), it must fit in at least one of the following boxes:

I would expect an error that says I have exceeded the number of allowable items in the particular box?

content.raw:
The code is coming along and seems very close to me.  I think we still need to clean up the associated wiki [#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/Creating%20a%20custom%20WAM-V%20Thruster%20and%20Sensor%20Configuration%20For%20Competition](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/Creating%20a%20custom%20WAM-V%20Thruster%20and%20Sensor%20Configuration%20For%20Competition)

My recommendations would be…

* Split into a few examples of increasing complexity

    * 1\) Generating URDF from default yaml files
    * 2\) Generating URDF from standard configuration yaml files \(standard thruster configs and standard sensor config examples\)
    * 3\) Generate URDF from custom configurations.
    
* Reference the VRX Technical Description document as the specification for compliance
* Illustrate what happens when

    * Things run correctly and are compliant
    * Things run correctly and are not compliant - explain that compliance is only an issue for VRX
    
* Have the examples we use be compliant.  The current example of three thrusters in the rear seems to suggest that this is a viable option.

‌

In general I think this is functionality that the teams will rely upon heavily, so anything we can do to make the process clear to them will save us time in the long run.
content.html:
The code is coming along and seems very close to me. I think we still need to clean up the associated wiki #!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/Creating%20a%20custom%20WAM-V%20Thruster%20and%20Sensor%20Configuration%20For%20Competition

My recommendations would be…

  • Split into a few examples of increasing complexity

    • 1) Generating URDF from default yaml files
    • 2) Generating URDF from standard configuration yaml files (standard thruster configs and standard sensor config examples)
    • 3) Generate URDF from custom configurations.

  • Reference the VRX Technical Description document as the specification for compliance

  • Illustrate what happens when

    • Things run correctly and are compliant
    • Things run correctly and are not compliant - explain that compliance is only an issue for VRX

  • Have the examples we use be compliant. The current example of three thrusters in the rear seems to suggest that this is a viable option.

‌

In general I think this is functionality that the teams will rely upon heavily, so anything we can do to make the process clear to them will save us time in the long run.

content.raw:
@{5ce2e28709c5fa0fd9fb0c6c} I just tried this out with multiple tests. Works exactly as expected. Looks great to me.

Just a few notes of ideas, don’t necessarily need to be in this PR:

* Could we have a boolean in compliance that is true if it passes all compliance tests and false otherwise. [#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/140/cpu-cases-now-included-when-configured-by/diff](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/140/cpu-cases-now-included-when-configured-by/diff) The Wiki is quite long and many users may miss the point about failing compliance still resulting in a urdf. If it fails, could we print a sentence like “This sensor and thruster configuration is NOT compliant with the \(current\) VRX constraints. A urdf file will still be created, but please note that the above errors must be fixed for this to be a valid configuration for the VRX competition.”
* I really like @{557058:6c52d6e5-77e0-41a8-8b6e-cb9462f4d5f1} 's idea of the X, T, H yaml files. Should we save that for another PR or add them here?
* @{557058:6c52d6e5-77e0-41a8-8b6e-cb9462f4d5f1} were you thinking of having automated tests to check that non-compliance happens on bad examples, or is something like the Wiki describes sufficiently?
* I’m not sure exactly how this can best be done, but I worry some really new Linux/ROS users may not understand parameters and defaults very well. It might be nice to add a print statement like “No thruster\_yaml given. Using default yaml defined at …example\_thruster\_config.yaml” if it is not given, so that they know that it is that default being used.
content.html:
@Marshall Rawson I just tried this out with multiple tests. Works exactly as expected. Looks great to me.

Just a few notes of ideas, don’t necessarily need to be in this PR:

  • Could we have a boolean in compliance that is true if it passes all compliance tests and false otherwise. #!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/140/cpu-cases-now-included-when-configured-by/diff The Wiki is quite long and many users may miss the point about failing compliance still resulting in a urdf. If it fails, could we print a sentence like “This sensor and thruster configuration is NOT compliant with the (current) VRX constraints. A urdf file will still be created, but please note that the above errors must be fixed for this to be a valid configuration for the VRX competition.”
  • I really like @Brian Bingham 's idea of the X, T, H yaml files. Should we save that for another PR or add them here?
  • @Brian Bingham were you thinking of having automated tests to check that non-compliance happens on bad examples, or is something like the Wiki describes sufficiently?
  • I’m not sure exactly how this can best be done, but I worry some really new Linux/ROS users may not understand parameters and defaults very well. It might be nice to add a print statement like “No thruster_yaml given. Using default yaml defined at …example_thruster_config.yaml” if it is not given, so that they know that it is that default being used.
